awd_titl_txt: Mechanisms of Peroxyl Radical Addition Reactions
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamic & Mechanism B Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Libin Xu of the Department of Medicinal Chemistry at the University of Washington aims to develop chemical tools to understand the reactivities and reaction mechanisms of oxidation of biologically important lipids. Understanding the fundamental chemistry underneath lipid peroxidation has broad impacts because lipid peroxidation plays significant roles in human pathologies, such as aging, atherosclerosis, and degenerative diseases. The project lies at the interface of physical organic chemistry and bioorganic chemistry and utilizes modern analytical chemistry techniques, and is well suited to the education of scientists with different training backgrounds.  This research group also aims to integrate education with the research plan by disseminating the knowledge of lipid peroxidation through outreach to high school students and teachers and attracting undergraduates from diverse backgrounds to the research field. 

The rate-determining step in lipid peroxidation is the propagation step of the peroxyl radical, where generally two types of reactions occur: a) hydrogen-atom transfer from a donor to the peroxyl radical; b) peroxyl-radical addition to a carbon-carbon double bond. The hydrogen-atom transfer mechanism is well studied, but much less is known about the reactivities and products of peroxyl-radical addition reactions. The goal of this project is to elucidate factors governing the reactivity of peroxyl-radical addition to a double bond and the contribution of this mechanism to peroxidation of a number of biologically important lipids, including cholesterol biosynthetic precursors, fat-soluble vitamins, and polyunsaturated fatty acids. There are three research objectives: 1) Establish a "radical clock" to measure the rate constants of both hydrogen-atom transfer and peroxyl-radical addition; 2) Evaluate factors controlling the reactivities of peroxyl-radical addition to a double bond; 3) Elucidate the products and reaction mechanisms of free radical peroxidation of biologically important lipids.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Lipid peroxidation is of high interest to both chemists and biologists as it displays complex but fascinating reaction mechanisms and plays important roles in human diseases. The rate-determining step in lipid peroxidation is the propagation step of the peroxyl radical, where generally two types of reactions occur: a) hydrogen-atom transfer (HAT) from a donor to the peroxyl radical; b) peroxyl-radical addition (PRA) to a C=C double bond. Chemical tools are available to measure the rate constants of HAT reactions, but no tool has been developed to measure the PRA reaction before this project. In this project, we developed a new peroxyl radical clock that enabled the differentiation of the peroxyl radical addition (PRA) rate constants from hydrogen-atom transfer (HAT) rate constants for the first time (Objective 1). We then applied the radical clock to the measurement of model organic molecules, such as a series of substituted styrenes and dienes, in order to understand electronic and steric factors affecting the reactivity of a molecule toward PRA reactions (Objective 2). Toward Objective 3, we first determined the overall propagation rate constant and separate HAT and PRA rate constants of some biologically important lipids, including sterols, vitamins A and D, coenzyme Q10, and conjugated polyunsaturated fatty acids (Figure 1). We then elucidated the product profiles of the peroxidation of several conjugated polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs) that are prone to both HAT and PRA-mediated oxidation, which validated the major role of the PRA mechanism.

Beyond lipid peroxidation chemistry, this project has broader impacts on human biology, diseases, and nutrition. Due to the close link between lipid peroxidation and various human diseases, such as cardiovascular diseases and Alzheimer’s disease, our fundamental understanding of the chemistry of such process would allow us to understand the roles of lipid oxidation in these diseases. Furthermore, since lipid peroxidation plays a central role in the execution of a new form of cell death - ferroptosis, understanding the reactivities of these lipids could allow us to assess whether they could play a role in ferroptosis in a particular biological environment. The finding of conjugated PUFAs being extremely oxidizable is surprising and may contribute to their anti-cancer activities. For example, parinaric acid, a conjugated fatty acid with four conjugated double bonds, is > 25 times more cytotoxic to cancer cells than corresponding non-conjugated fatty acids. Conjugated linolenic acid (with three conjugated double bonds) was recently found to significantly sensitize triple-negative cancer cells to ferroptosis. Conjugated PUFAs are commonly found in meat and dairy products from ruminants and plant-based food products such as pomegranate and bitter gourd seeds. Thus, elucidation of the oxidation mechanism of these compounds could shed light on the impact of intake of CLA-containing foods on human health and provide the basis for evaluating the biological activities of the oxidation products of these lipids.

This project has made a significant impact on the education, recruitment, and retention of the next generation of scientists. One graduate student based her PhD thesis on this project and another graduate student has received partial support on the development of analytical assays. Five undergraduate researchers recruited from the University of Washington have received training in lab techniques and career development with the support of this project. Their contribution has resulted or will result in co-authorships in our publications. These undergraduate students have all gone on to graduate school, pharmacy school, or medical school. We have also hosted an undergraduate researcher from the Pharmaceutical Sciences Summer Diversity Program and disseminated our research to five summer undergraduate students who are underrepresented minorities from the Summer Health Professionals Education Program at the University of Washington.


Last Modified: 11/25/2022
Modified by: Libin Xu
